reviewText: We've all seen the aerial shot of the Warner Bros. sound stages in Hollywood.  When those stages and the studio system were functioning at peak efficiency, the home to Bugs and Bogie knocked out a series of well over 60 black-and-white comic shorts, all starring George O'Hanlon as the hapless Everyguy Joe McDoakes.  They ran from 1942 to 1956 in movie houses along with WB feature films and the well-remembered Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies. Now at long last we have the JOE McDOAKES COLLECTION (sometimes called "Behind the Eight Ball"), assembling all the O'Hanlon shorts except for a handful not directed by usual writer / director Richard Bare.It's astonishing how good these eleven-minute, one-reeler shorts can be, and how much incident is packed into them. Every title starts out with the word "So . . . ?" as in "So You Think You're a Nervous Wreck?", "So You Want to Run for Office?", "So You Want to be a Door-to-door Salesman?" and so on.  The tone of the comedy is often bright and sophisticated:  A narrator tells us that poor Joe, out of his element at a businessman's lunch, is trying to "make his way in our complex civilization," and winds up under the care of a quack psychoanalyst.  "So You Want to Hold a Party?" has a sleep-deprived Joe mixing up his party list with his creditors' list, so that everyone he owes money to shows up to hear Joe brag about his financial acumen.  What succeeds the most at this party, though, is wife Alice's popularity as Postmistress in an ongoing game of Post Office where the wife takes her "deliveries" quite out of sight of the main party. . . returning with mussed hair and all.  But there is room for other comedic approaches as well: a Walter Mittyesque fantasy that spins through Joe's mind in a movie theater while he and his wife watch a Western gives us the gold of "So You Want to be a Cowboy?"  "So You Want to Move?" is a more slapstick affair that shifts into high gear when Joe refuses to pay $150 (well, it was the Forties) to a moving company and tries to do the job himself with pick-up labor and creaky vans . . .  with the situation deteriorating more than anyone, least of all Joe, could have predicted.A signal pleasure for those of us who revere the era of 'Classic Cinema' comes from the handsome production values this long-lived series received.  Over at tightfisted Columbia, filming the Three Stooges' comic genius usually involved room-to-room tracking shots and simple props like wallpaper and paste.  McDoakes's world, though, plays out more like a string of miniature Warner Grade A comedies, employing not only sharp writing but more than enough cast to get the job done, terrific special effects, and often no end of exterior shoots.  Except for a couple of stock characters like Joe's bully and nemesis, Homer Hotbox, and the office flirt Bessie Backspace, featured actors come and go fairly quickly. Look quick for stars on the rise or already established, like Pamela Albritton, Fred Clarke, "Ronnie" Reagan (REE-gun), and Doris Day.  Joe himself is married to a bunch of different Alices, some more shrill than others, before the studio settled on Phyllis Coates for most of the series' remaining run.Although this very reasonably priced set of DVD's consists of made-on-demand pressings, there was no indication that quality or durability suffered, and delivery time was not delayed.  Except for a very, very occasional showing on the Turner Classic Movies network, or as a side note in a couple of Warner DVD's, you can't see much of Joe McDoakes without buying this collection.  Trivia note:  Does actor O'Hanlon's voice sound familiar to you?  In 1962 he became the voice of George Jetson..

reviewText: What a great set! His work has been out of circulation for so long. It's great to see Joe on DVD, and the transfers are really good. Love it.

reviewText: Never heard of Joe McDoakes? "Behind The Eight Ball?" Well, it's worth your while to discover them. This was a series of 63 ten minute comedy shorts that were produced from the 1940's until the mid-fifties about everyman Joe McDoakes (played perfectly by George O' Hanlon). These are high quality shorts: their budgets appear to have been quite high, the writing is consistently good to excellent, and the acting (comic acting, with an emphasis on comic: O'Hanlon was great in these and should have been given feature-length films to do) is excellent. The titles, i.e., "So you want to give up smoking...hold your wife...etc." are nothing but excuses for the ensemble crew of director/write Richard Bare, O'Hanlon, etc., to let loose and create some very funny bits (I almost lost it when I saw Joe and wife Alice screaming at each other over Thanksgiving plans in "So you want to hold your wife"! Who can't relate to a family holiday being ruined by family disagreements?). The series starts out with "So you want to give up smoking" and begins with some uncertainty about how much the crew wants to be amusingly educational and how much they want to go full-steam ahead with doing nothing but comedy. Lucky for us, comedy won out! The series - and O'Hanlon - gets better and better with each short. By 1946, O'Hanlon has the character down pat: an average Joe facing the frustrations of life with perseverance, a quick temper, and co-workers, friends, and family member who only seem to make things more difficult. I bought this when it was much cheaper than what Amazon is charging at present. I guess demand is good and they can get away with it. If it comes down in price, and you are a fan of comedy shorts, grab this.
Title: N/A

reviewText: George O'Hanlon played Joe McDoakes in 63 shorts for Warner Bros form 1942-1956 and later became the voice of George Jetson in the Hanna-Barbera TV cartoon series. Phyllis Coates played McDoakes wife from 1948-1954 until she got the role as Lois Lane in TV's Adventures of Superman. She also returned to play the wife in the final installment "So Your Wife Wants to Work" in 1956. Here is a list of the shorts in this 648 minute, 6 DVD set:So You Want to Give Up Smoking (1942a)So You Think You Need Glasses  (1942b)So You Think You're Allergic  (1945)So You Want to Play the Horses (1946a)So You Want to Keep Your Hair (1946b)So You Think You're a Nervous Wreck (1946c)So You're Going to Be a Father (1947a)So You Want to Be in Pictures (1947b)So You're Going on a Vacation Be a Detective (1948d)So You Want to Be in Politics (1948e)So You Want to Be on the Radio (1948f)So You Want to Be a Baby-Sitter (1949a)So You Want to Be Popular (1949b)So You Want to Be a Muscle Man (1949c)So You're Having In-Law Trouble (1949d)So You Want to Get Rich Quick (1949e)So You Want to Be an Actor (1949f)So You Want to Throw a Party (1950a)So You Think You're Not Guilty (1950b)So You Want to Hold Your Husband (1950c)So You Want to Move (1950d)So You Want a Raise  (1950e)So You're Going to Have an Operation (1950f)So You Want to Be a Handyman  (1951a)So You Want to Be a Cowboy  (1951b)So You Want to Be a Paperhanger  (1951c)So You Want to Buy a Used Car (1951d)So You Want to Be a Bachelor  (1951e)So You Want to Be a Plumber (1951f)So You Want to Get It Wholesale (1952a)So You Want to Enjoy Life (1952b)So You're Going to a Convention (1952c)So You Never Tell a Lie (1952d)So You're Going to the Dentist (1952e)So You Want to Wear the Pants (1952f)So You Want to Be a Musician (1953a)So You Want to Learn to Dance  (1953b)So You Want a Television Set (1953c)So You Love Your Dog (1953d)So You Think You Can't Sleep  (1953e)So You Want to Be an Heir (1953f)So You're Having Neighbor Trouble (1954a)So You Want to Be Your Own Boss (1954b)So You Want to Go to a Nightclub (1954c)So You Want to Be a Banker (1954d)So You're Taking in a Roomer (1954e)So You Want to Know Your Relatives (1954f)So You Don't Trust Your Wife  (1955a)So You Want to Be a Gladiator (1955b)So You Want to Be on a Jury  (1955c)So You Want to Build a Model Railroad (1955d)So You Want to Be a V.P. (1955e)So You Want to Be a Policeman (1955f)So You Think the Grass Is Greener (1956a)So You Want to Be Pretty (1956b)So You Want to Play the Piano (1956c)So Your Wife Wants to Work (1956d)Guest cast notable for other roles:Arthur Q. Bryan, the voice of Elmer Fudd, appeared on screen in So You Want to Build a Model Railroad(1955) and filled in for Art Gilmore as the narrator in So You Want to Be a Policeman.(1955)George Chandler and Ronald Reagan, both of whom would later be President of the Screen Actors Guild (SAG), appeared in the same short, So You Want to Be in Pictures.(1947)Iron Eyes Cody offered a "scalp" treatment to Joe in So You Want to Keep Your Hair.(1946)The screen duo of Doris Day and Gordon MacRae has a cameo in So You Want a Television Set.(1953)Charlie Hall, who served as the foil in many Laurel and Hardy shorts, had his last screen appearance in So You Want to Play the Piano.(1956)Lyle Talbot, a founding member of SAG, was in So You Want to Be Your Own Boss.(1954)
summary: Before GEORGE JETSON there was JOE McDOAKES!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I loved these! I saw a couple of these back in the early days of the Comedy Channel when, wouldn't you know it, they used to show funny material. Dating from 1940s to the 1950s McDoakes deals with all sorts of issues involving modern life: housing, doctors, politics and technology, to name just a few things. Hanlon plays McDoakes, and if his voice sounds familiar it's because he did the voice of George Jetson.

reviewText: I heard of Joe from a hobby friend of mine. I have been looking for an item like this for 5 years. This was even better than I expected. Good old American humor from a guy who is always behind the 8 ball.
Title: N/A

reviewText: These comedy shorts are Great. If your into old fashioned comedy this is probably for you. I'm too young to have seen these first hand. But I know who George Jetson is. In fact that's how I found this set. I was watching TCM and in between movies they played (So your wife wants to work). I thought it was pretty funny, but I didn't notice the name. I realized this guy was George Jetson. So I looked up who did the voice for George Jetson, typed that name into Amazon Movies and up came this set. I had no idea this many shorts were made. But I'm glad. They're hilarious. My wife got them for me for Christmas. Yes they are dvd-r's. But I new that before my wife got them. I thought they were nicely done. I was very satisfied. I know they might seem a little pricey, but it is probably a limited market.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I purchased this after my dad told me he had seen them as a young boy. They are great classic shorts and George O'Hanlon is perfect in the part of the man behind the eight ball. I recommend this to all who love the old shorts of yesteryear.
